segments.text: I think this is I think this kind of thing is probably sorely needed and I say that partly because right now we've got a new department head and and I'm sure that and we've got six people in soil science retiring me being one of them Milford being another and others coming so so we need uh uh
We need to be able to look at ourselves differently.
I think we need to be able to look at ourselves department, experiment station, and college.
And I wish there were a way that the university could assess all levels of performance.
We're not like industry, and I don't think we should do things quite the same way that they do necessarily.
But on the other hand, I think we have to face the same reality as they do.
And I think the sooner we can...
Here's something that's in the university that I think is a real deterrent.
Too many long titles.
What does one know about a man who's got, he's dean, he's director, he's, you know, and on and on and on.
I know from, it just happens my wife writes very well by hand.
She has addressed lots of invitations for certain people on this campus in high places.
Whenever you have to cover up half of the envelope with a man's titles, that's something's out of line as far as the public goes.
And I think we need to streamline titles some way and make them functional.
And I suspect we probably ought to streamline the amount of tenure that people have in a given administrative post, even though it's comfortable for people.
And I have a high regard for our administrators.
I think probably some more changes are needed.
All right.
I have just about finished all of the questions I have.
What have we not touched on that we should have?
I would say that one of the nice things about here is that we do have the opportunity to interact with some very nice students in social settings.
It just happens that I go to the church across the street.
not that it wouldn't have been just as well as many others, but what you'd say the student foundations around our campus certainly
being a part of those and interacting with the students in those is a privilege and an opportunity and an important part of our academic life, as I see.
And I haven't done more than my share, but I've enjoyed what I've done.
And I hope to continue some of that.
I think that we all need to keep our breadth
Just as I said earlier that I go on field trips a lot.
I don't know what kind of field trips people need in other disciplines, but in soil science you have to go into the field.
And one of the things that I worked into to my core teaching some years ago
was a half-day field trip in which I try to illustrate the high points of the course in terms of minerals.
And that's evolved through our research.
And every site we go to, we have some kind of a research base for 20 specimens of different conditions, wetlands, mine lands, soil.
And I think that's important.
One thing that I didn't mention, for I think 16 years, I was the chair of the teaching clay mineralogy symposium of the International Clay Society.
It meets every four years.
Well, that was a great opportunity.
It kind of fitted in with the fact that I taught seminar for about that number of years in the department, graduate seminar in soil science.
And I was privileged in that to interact with a diversity of people and ask them to participate as well as put something into the program myself.
And I think that we need more of that as far out as we can reach.
Sigma Xi and the people in chemistry have done the best job that I know about on campus by cutting across scientific barriers and bringing people together.
There's a little chemistry in so many phases of science, and a whole lot of some.
And I think that sort of thing is really important.
And in this chromium work that I mentioned to you,
I got down to the end of publishing that paper and got a really good set of reviews on that manuscript.
And one of them said you should have data on the electronic status of those manganese oxides.
Well, that was not something I had ever done.
Didn't have an instrument in my department to do that.
So I ferreted out a person in chemistry who turned out to be a well-spoken Chinaman who had finished his doctor's degree in chemistry and was badly needed in publication.
very much agreed if he had helped me define the electronic status in those minerals.
And within a week, we had done the most of that.
And it'll appear in the journal within the next few months.
And so that's the kind of cross-fertilization that we need a lot more of.
And I think we'd welcome a lot of administrators back into the teaching lecture halls and back into the research laboratories if that could ever be managed.
Anything else we've left out that we need to be sure to cover?
I think every scientist needs some skills in addition to theory.
Mine happens to be electron microscopy and x-ray diffraction and a few of those.
You sound like a land grant person as compared to a theoretical university person.
Yes, that's right.
I mentioned sabbaticals.
The travel is really important and it's built well into my profession.
And I think that, I don't know how it fits everybody, but I think a great many of us as scholars, we need to do a significant amount of traveling.
How adequate have you found the library resources here when you needed?
They have generally been quite good.
Being in a focused area, and I have usually taken
Sometimes as many as 12 journals, right now it's not that many.
But I have my library, three different bookcases in a row in my office.
And my group uses them more than any others.
And the computer is helping us a lot in that regard.
But I think we just, as I see it, we sort of gradually kept ahead of not being so good.
Like the library that's been built on West Campus is a tremendous asset to us.
But we've got to equip it with our journals and things.
Just as we're doing that, we're merging into the electronic age of publishing, and we don't quite know how that's all going to come together.
So I guess we have to run faster.
Something that I've touched on just a little, and I'll just mention again, and that is that, and this is something I have invested a little of my own money into through a scholarship,
having readily available money.
so that when a scientist from anywhere in the world says, I want to come and work with you for a summer or a term or a month or something, you can say with confidence, well, we can work it out.
And we do much better at complimenting people for what they want to do.
In this case, it would be kind of like a mini sabbatical type of thing.
Or maybe it would.
with somebody else's money make it into a sabbatical.
We're always, I think, having opportunities with people from Africa or the Middle East or some remote little tropical country that has very limited resources and equipment.
They need to have some help, and they have the least money.

and of course the same thing applies to students but it can work here again we have to get out of our box it can work helping graduate students it can also work helping a faculty member who has to go back and support his family in mexico but he can work in increments it challenges our degree granting way of doing they may end up getting his
doctor's degree in Mexico and doing his basic research at A&M, but that's all right if that's what it takes, as I see it.
I've encountered that.
I think you've done well.
Should A&M attempt to get any larger?
That's kind of like asking about gravity or the weather.
I think it's really hard to give a good answer on that.
I'd say that's not probably going to be decided by faculty like me.
I would say what we need to do, we need to create
cultural villages, scientific and cultural villages, and promote the interaction within them and among them.
And that's the way I believe we can meet the public's need and meet our local need.
We just finished.
Last year we had a little black young lady from Corpus to come and work.
She's a junior in high school.
This is a part of their programs.
They called it ALPS program, moving to higher planes.
This year they called it high school student research.
Less students.
We had one from Houston this year.

When that student came in, tall, very attractive, both McGann and other, black student, doesn't matter with me, very well groomed, presented herself very well, came out of I think one of the best high schools in Houston area, call it a century school I think.
She had much more spirit.
After she interacted with that group,
I think she turned back into her high schoolish perspective.
And as I look at it, we accomplished quite a lot.
And so much so I'm trying to get her data book back now.
She took it with her and we're exchanging letters and phone calls on that.
But that experience in those two years has taught me that we need to
we need to help these young people when they come in, fit into our cultural setting in a constructive way.
And if I were doing it, if I had to have one next summer, which I have no idea whether I will or not, I will make it a point to spend myself or somebody in my group
every lunch hour for the first week with that young person.
Showing them different things that relate to the culture of the campus or relate to the science we're trying to project.
And not let them get back into this very immature teenage frame.
That's all I can say.
All right, my next to last question then.
Let's make believe someone hands you a check for a million dollars.
with one condition, you must pass that check on to Texas A&M, but you decide what is to be done with that money.
If you had the capability to make a meaningful gift to Texas A&M, for what purpose would you want the gift used?
What's your favorite project or task or game?
Well, you know, you really, excuse me,
You really put me on the spot, because I'm obviously very selfishly oriented about something I know something about that I've studied about for a long time.
I think if I had a million dollars with the freedom to use it in Texas A&M,
I would try to set up a program that embraced the most basic parts of the science that I know something about, soils and such, and extend it to include the consumer.
In other words, I would try to integrate basic research and extension as it's perceived in a classic sense.
And I'd like to apply it perhaps to a given kind of a problem for maybe for five years.
And then try to wrap it up and then perhaps move to another kind of a problem for the next five years.
And pull in faculty into that.

And that way we could not only be seeing what we do at the molecular level here, and a lot of our science can be done at the molecular level and move ahead much faster, but we need to spend part of our time out there in the applications area.
And I think with that kind of an assemblage and an active group,
I think it would be, we could efficiently use the resources from a million dollars.
Okay, last question.
After about a third of a century here, what feelings do you carry in your heart for Texas A&M?
Well, it's a great place to work.
It's a great place to work because it offers a lot of freedom, it offers quite a bit of support.
It's dwindling in some respects.
Not in every respect.
The student money that's been plowed back into our department has been our salvation in recent years.
I don't know if that's the best way to go or not, but that's the way it's going.
It certainly helps.
I'm just, I'm kind of tired now, and I guess I didn't do very well with your last question.
No, no, no.
Say again what your last question was.
What feelings do you carry in your heart about Texas A&M?
I'm not beyond being emotional, but I'm not very emotional, really.
I'm more factual oriented, I think.
I really like the

the high purpose that A&M has exemplified in its selection of leaders, and the fact that I've gotten to know a significant number of them, but I don't go out beating the bushes to meet people very much.
And I'm glad to be able to go anywhere else in the country and say I work for Texas A&M, and there are a lot of good people there doing their best.
And there's a good ending right there.
